abstract.p: Letter from Alan Drewsen (International Trademark Assn) holds governments need to take more aggressive steps to protect trademark owners against counterfeit goods in international trade

block.p: You point out China's difficulty curtailing patent and copyright piracy within its own borders (Business Day, Oct. 4). But patents and copyrights are only part of a bigger picture.

Trademark owners invest millions of dollars in trade. Counterfeit goods currently make up as much as 30 percent of all international trade, a problem that casts a dark shadow over global commerce, not just trading with China.
You point out China's difficulty curtailing patent and copyright piracy within its own borders (Business Day, Oct. 4). But patents and copyrights are only part of a bigger picture.

Trademark owners invest millions of dollars in trade. Counterfeit goods currently make up as much as 30 percent of all international trade, a problem that casts a dark shadow over global commerce, not just trading with China.
The purpose of a trademark is to help to preserve a product's integrity, ensuring quality control, fulfilling product warranties and, ultimately, maintaining a high level of consumer protection.

Governments need to take more aggressive steps to protect the intellectual property rights of businesses so consumers do not get hurt. Otherwise, we risk having rampant counterfeiting operations continually undermining global economic progress.
ALAN DREWSEN Executive Director, International Trademark Association New York, Oct. 6, 2000
